newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Shaky sellers see Australian stocks end down.
newsitem.headline: Shaky sellers see Australian stocks end down.

text.p: The Australian sharemarket closed lower on Tuesday with losses steepening in the afternoon as nervous investors trimmed positions ahead of the U.S. opening.
At the close, the All Ordinaries index was down 19.8 points at 2,262.3. The September share index futures slid 21 points to 2,266 and was at a 3.7 point premium to the underlying index.
Brokers said selling emerged following weakness in both local and U.S. bond markets with investors worried U.S. yields would continue to rise after nudging seven percent on Monday.
"It's taken a dive today," said a Sydney-based dealer.
"There are plenty of sellers about although volumes are not exceptional," he said.
Turnover at A$641 million was substantial, though suggestive of a hedging of positions rather than a wholesale selldown.

"Commonwealth Bank going ex-dividend had an effect but overall it's been taken down by selling from people worried about U.S. (interest) rates. Positions are being cut while things are sorted out over there," the dealer said.
Others saw things in the same light, saying a lack of positive inspiration had seen recent strong profits cashed in.
"With no guidance people have sold off and taken some profits," said dealer Peter Struk of brokerage Reynolds and Co.
In corporate features, aluminium producer Comalco continued to slide after Monday's disappointing profit result. Its 67 percent shareholder, CRA, saw its shares soften in sympathy.
Engineering and hardware group Howard Smith bucked the trend to finish stronger after reporting a 12 percent higher full year net profit of A$86.13 million.
Falls outnumbered rises by a ratio of about nine to seven, while about 33 percent of stocks traded remained steady.
